author: @user-fm4hd6wr4k
text: Here is the Lu Wu team. We will improve the python library and ros package files as soon as possible. Thank you for your support. The audience's suggestions for us can be written below this comment, and we will continue to improve XGO. We hope to provide the best desktop quadruped robot development platform. Thank you for your love and support.

author: @rsuriyop
text: All of this programming and re-engineering looks pretty complex. I was pretty intent on getting an XGO Mini Lite for simple fun. But I don't want to bother doing any of this complex stuff. I'm just interested in making it go wherever I want under my control or to set it free on some kind of autonomous self-exploration mode.

text: I'm not 100% sure on the scale; but kinda looks like it might be possible for it to climb human stairs by sitting on the back legs, balancing on the lower segments of the rear legs for stability; then reach with the front legs over the step, reaching as far forward as possible before placing the front feet down; then carefully raising itself on it's rear and front feet, then  once the rear legs are stretched the most and the hips are close to the edge of the step, carefully get the rear feet over onto the step one at a time, being sure to move the center of gravity forward so it's above the step.

author: @johanlarsson9805
text: 2:20 Holy crap, that is the dumbest title of a book I have ever heard. I've been interested in neural nets since 2007, built my first 2008 and made my own framework back in 2010.  You do not create neural nets in python from scratch... you do it in c++. The only reason AI-wannabees even think python is a valid appraoch is because of Tensorflow, which again is c++ under the hood.
